s.word: Sententia interlocutoria revocari potest, definitiva non potest
s.meaning: An interlocutory order can be revoked, a final order cannot be.

s.word: Sic utere tuo ut alienum non laedas
s.meaning: So use your own as not to injure another s property.
A simple recommendation does not bind
damages given by way of reparation for injury to feelings
Do not delete, let it stand
The cause being removed, the effect ceases
The foundation being removed, the structure falls.
A subsequent marriage removes the preceding wrong.
The suggestion of something which is untrue

s.word: Summa ratio est quae pro religione facit
s.meaning: The highest reason is that which makes for religion, i.e. religion dictates.
A suppression of truth is equivalent to an expression of falsehood.

t.meaning: Things silent are sometimes considered as expressed.

t.word: Talis interpretatio semper fienda est, ut evitetur absurdum, et inconveniens, et ne judicium sit ill
t.meaning: Interpretation is always to be made in such a manner, that what is absurd and inconvenient is to be avoided, so that the judgment be not nugatory.

t.word: Talis non est eadem, nam nullum simile est idem.
t.meaning: What is like is not the same, for nothing similar is the same.
Such as it is

t.word: Tantum bona valent, quantum vendi possunt.
t.meaning: Things are worth what they will sell for.

t.word: Terminus annorum certus debet esse et determinatus.
t.meaning: A term of years ought to be certain and determinate.
Solid ground.
Land passses with the incumbrances.
third party
test
This is supposed to be the test word
Wills ough to have the broadest interpretation.
Every will is completed by death.

t.word: Testatoris ultima voluntas est perimplenda secundum veram intentionem suam.
t.meaning: The last will of a testator is to be fulfilled according to his real intention.

t.word: Testibus deponentibus in pari numero dignioribus est credendum.
t.meaning: When the number of witnesses is equal on both sides, the more worthy are to be believed.
An eye witness outweighs others.

t.word: Testis nemo in su caus esse potest.
t.meaning: No one can be a witness in his own cause.

t.word: Testis oculatus unus plus valet quam auriti decem.
t.meaning: One eye witness is worth ten ear witnesses.

t.word: Timores vani sunt aestimandi qui non cadunt in constantem virum.
t.meaning: Fears, which have no fixed persons for their object, are vain.

t.word: Tonte exception non surveill e tend prendre la place du principe.
t.meaning: Every exception not watched tends to assume the place of the principle.
The whole is preferable to any single part.

t.word: Tout ce que la loi ne defend pas est permis.
t.meaning: Everything is permitted, which is not forbidden by law.
Let smiths perform the work of smiths.
Delivery makes a deed speak
Delivery makes the deed speak.
When transgression is multiplied, let the infliction of punishment be increased.
The land passes with its burden

t.word: Triatio ibi semper debet fieri, ubi juratores meliorem possunt habere notitiam.
t.meaning: Trial ought always to be had where the jury have the best knowledge.

t.word: Trupis est pars quae non convenit cum suo toto.
t.meaning: That part is bad which accords not with the whole.

t.word: Tuta est custodia quae sibimet creditur.
t.meaning: That guardianship is secure which trusts to itself alone.
It is safer to err on the side of mercy.

u.word: uberrima fides
u.meaning: the utmost good faith

u.word: Ubi aliquid impeditur propter unum, eo remoto, tollitur impedimentum.
u.meaning: When anything is impeded by one single cause, if that be removed the impediment is removed.

u.word: Ubi cessat remedium ordinarium ibi decurritur ad extraordinarium.
u.meaning: When a common remedy ceases to be of service, recoruse must be had to an extraordinary one

u.word: Ubi culpa est ibi paena subesse debet.
u.meaning: Where there is culpability, there punishment ought to be.

u.word: Ubi damna dantur, victus victori in expensis condemnari debet.
u.meaning: Where damages are given, the losing party should pay the costs of the victor.

u.word: Ubi eadem ratio ibi idem jus, et de similibus idem est judicium
u.meaning: When there is the same reason, then the law is the same, and the same judgment should be rendered as to similar things.

u.word: Ubi eadem ratio, ibi idem lex.
u.meaning: Where there is the same reason, there is the same law.

u.word: Ubi factum nullum ibi sortia nulla.
u.meaning: Where there is no deed committed, there can be no consequence.

u.word: Ubi jus ibi remedium est
u.meaning: Where there is a right there is a remedy.

u.word: Ubi jus incertum, ibi jus nullum.
u.meaning: Where the law is uncertain, there is no law.

u.word: Ubi jus, ibi remedium.
u.meaning: Where there is a right, there is a remedy.

u.word: Ubi lex aliquem cogit ostendere causam, necesse est quod causa sit justa et letitima.
u.meaning: Where the law compels a man to show cause, the cause ought to be just and legal.

u.word: Ubi lex est specialis, et ratio ejus generalis, generaliter accipienda est.
u.meaning: Where the law is special and the reason of it is general, it ought to be taken as being general.

u.word: Ubi lex non distinguit, nec nos distinguere debemus.
u.meaning: Where the law does not distinguish, we ought not to distinguish.

u.word: Ubi major pars est, ibi totum.
u.meaning: Where is the greater part, there is the whole.

u.word: Ubi non adest norma legis, omnia quasi pro suspectis habenda sunt.
u.meaning: When the law fails to serve as a rule, almost everything ought to be suspected. Bacon,

u.word: Ubi non est condendi auctoritas, ibi non est parendi necessitas.
u.meaning: Where there is no authority to enforce, there is no authority to obey.

u.word: Ubi non est directa lex, standum est arbitrio judicis, vel procedendum ad similia.
u.meaning: Where there is no direct law, the opinion of the judges ought to be taken, or reference made to similar cases.

u.word: Ubi non est lex, non est transgressio quoad mundum.
u.meaning: Where there is no law there is no transgression, as it regards the world.

u.word: ubi nullum matrimonium ibi nullum dos.
u.meaning: Where there is no marriage there is no dower.

u.word: Ubi nullum matrimonium, ibi nulla dos es
u.meaning: Where there is no marriage, there is no dower.

u.word: Ubi periculum, ibi et lucrum collocatur.
u.meaning: He at whose risk a thing is, should receive the profits arising from it.

u.word: Ubi quid generaliter conceditur, in est haec exceptio, si non aliquid sit contra jus fasque.
u.meaning: Where a thing is concealed generally, this exception arises, that there shall be nothing contrary to law and right.

u.word: ubi quis delinquit ibi punietur.
u.meaning: Let a man be punished when he commits the offence.

u.word: Ubicunque est injuria, ibi damnum sequitur.
u.meaning: Whereever there is a wrong, there damages follow.

u.word: Ultima voluntas testatoris est perimplenda secundum veram intentionem suam.
u.meaning: The last will of a testator is to be fulfilled according to his true intention.

u.word: ultimum refugium
u.meaning: last resort

u.word: ultimus haeres
u.meaning: last heir; the Crown inherits as last heir for want of other heirs

u.word: Ultra posse non est esse, et vice versa.
u.meaning: What is beyond possibility cannot exist, and the reverse, what cannot exist is not possible.

u.word: Una persona vix potest supplere vices duorum.
u.meaning: One person can scarcely supply the place of two.

u.word: Universalia sunt notoria singularibus.
u.meaning: Things universal are better known than things particular.

u.word: Universitas vel corporatio non dicitur aliquid facere nisi id sit collegialiter deliberatum, etiamsi
u.meaning: An university or corporation is not said to do anything unless it be deliberated upon collegiately, although the majority should do it.

u.word: Uno absurdo dato, infinita sequuntur.
u.meaning: One absurdity begin allowed, an infinity follow.

u.word: uno flatu
u.meaning: at the same moment; with one breath

u.word: Unumquodque dissolvatur eo modo quo colligatur.
u.meaning: Everything is dissolved by the same mode in which it is bound together.

u.word: Unumquodque eodem modo quo colligatum est dissolvitur.
u.meaning: In the same manner in which a thing is bound, it is loosened.

u.word: Unumquodque est id quod est principalius in ipso.
u.meaning: That which is the principal part of a thing is the thing itself.

u.word: Ut res magis valeat quam pereat.
u.meaning: That the thing may rather have effect than be destroyed.

u.word: Utile per inutile non vitiatur.
u.meaning: What is useful is not vitiated by the useless.

v.meaning: It shall have effect as far as it can have effect.

v.word: Vana est illa potentia quae numquam venit in actum.
v.meaning: Vain is that power which is never brought into action.

v.word: Vani timores sunt aestimandi, qui non cadunt in constantem virum.
v.meaning: Vain are those fears which affect not a valiant man.

v.word: Vendens eandem rem doubus falsarius est.
v.meaning: It is fraudulent to sell the same thing twice.
Facility of pardon is an incentive to crime.

v.word: Verba aequivoca ac in dubio sensu posita, intelliguntur dignori et potentiori sensu.
v.meaning: Equivocal words and those in a doubtful sense are to be taken in their best and most effective sense.

v.word: Verba chartarum fortius accipiuntur contra preferentem
v.meaning: The words of deeds are accepted more strongly against the person offering them.

v.word: Verba currentis monetae, tempus solutionis designat.
v.meaning: The words current money, refer to the time of payment
Words ought to be understood with effect.

v.word: Verba dicta de persona, intelligi debent de conditione personae.
v.meaning: Words spoken of the person are to be understood of the condition of the person
Words are to be taken most strongly against him who uses them.

v.word: Verba ganeralia restringuntur ad habilitatem rei vel personae.
v.meaning: General words must be confined or restrained to the nature of the subject or the aptitude of the person.
General words are to be generally understood.

v.word: Verba intentioni, non e contra, debent inservire.
v.meaning: Words ought to be made subservient to the intent, not contrary to it.

v.word: Verba ita sunt intelligenda, ut res magis valeat quam pereat.
v.meaning: Wrods are to be so understood that the subject-matter may be preserved rather than destroyed.

v.word: Verba nihil operandi melius est quam absurde.
v.meaning: It is better that words should have no operation, than to operate absurdly.

v.word: Verba posteriora propter certitudinem addita, ad priora quae certitudine indigent, sunt referenda.
v.meaning: Words added for the purpose of certainty are to be referred to preceding words, in which certainty is wanting.
Word by word, exactly.

v.word: Veredictum, quasi dictum veritas; ut judicium quasi juris dictum.
v.meaning: A verdict is, as it were, the saying of the truth, in the same manner that a judgment is the saying of the law

v.word: Verga relata hac maximi operantur per referentiam ut in eis in esse videntur.
v.meaning: Words referred to other words operate chiefly by the reference which appears to be impled towards them.
truth
The truth of the demonstration removes the error of the name
Truth fears nothing but concealment.
By too much altercation truth is lost.

v.word: Veritatem qui non libere pronunciat, proditor est veritatis.
v.meaning: He who does not speak the truth, is a traitor to the truth.
With the force and arms.
The old way is the safe way.
A deputy cannot appoint a deputy.
The other way around.
See

v.word: Vigilantibus et non dormientibus serviunt leges.
v.meaning: The laws serve the vigilant, not those who sleep upon their rights
The laws serve the vigilant, not those who sleep.

v.word: Viperina est expositio quae corrodit viscera textus.
v.meaning: That is a viperous exposition which gnaws or eats out the bowels of the text.

v.word: Vir et uxor consentur in lege una persona.
v.meaning: Husband and wife are considered one person in law.
force and fear
Force is inimical to the laws.
We recommend a visitation.
Clerical errors ought not to hurt.
An inherent taint or defect in a title to property (also known as labes realis)
Willing.
An injury is not done to one consenting to it.
he willed but did not say.

v.word: Voluntas in delictis non exitus spectatur.
v.meaning: In offences, the will and not the consequences are to be looked to.
The will is taken for the deed

v.word: Voluntas testatoris ambulatoria est usque ad mortem.
v.meaning: The will of a testator is ambulatory until his death; that is, he may change it at any time.
He who consents cannot receive an injury.

v.word: Vreba aliquid operari debent, verba cum effectu sunt accipienda.
v.meaning: Words are to be taken so as to have effect.
